episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: This is Jonathan Peugeot. Welcome to the symbolic world. So hello everybody. I am sitting here with Neil Degrade. Neil Degrade is a musician. He is the headliner for a band called Dirt Poor Robbins. But he's also done so much in the music world, written scores for movies, for different shows. He's been in several bands and he's also become quite a participant in the symbolic world. He is in contact with a lot of people that are kind of swirling around the videos. I've been in discussion with him for several. For like years now or like over a year. Over a year now. And we're also looking at doing some projects together. So I'm really excited to have him on the show. Mostly to talk about how it is that artists can predict the future.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Neil Degrade
text: Oh, this is where I talk. If I was good at predicting the future, I could have predicted that. Oh, that's a good setup. I like that. This is a great topic. I guess I gotta give you a little background. Yep. So I. I was born into a family of entertainers and musicians. So both sides of my family pretty much across the board, all musical, all entertainers, most and many professional at one point. Really funny thing I like to tell people is that I found my parents marriage certificate and on the marriage certificate back then in the 60s, you had to put your parents occupation. So my dad's father, he was a radio announcer entertainer and my mom's father was a radio announcer entertainer. So there was a part of my. I think I was to be on the radio and just missed like stepped out of the stable and missed my calling. So. But it was a family of entertainers and so there was no question that I was going to learn music. It was going to be forced on me whether I liked it or not. And it turned out that I really liked it. So my dad used to bring home records from the radio station and the first one I ever get I think really explains what we're doing the best because he brought home two records for me and my brother to pick from. One was Kiss, and the other one was Queen. It was News of the World and my brother picked Kiss. And if you listen to Kiss and what they've stated their goal was, Gene Simmons says, we weren't trying to be the Beatles like every other band. We wanted to be Coca Cola. And that's like totally my brother. He's like brilliant with marketing and he's had an incredible career with that and he's kind of went off that way. And I picked Queen, which Queen I think was trying to Be an opera or a movie. And so that just blew my tiny mind. And the artwork on that record was like this Isaac Asimov take where there was this giant robot. I guess we could pull this up while I'm saying this, but was killing the members of the band. And it really tripped my little 5 year old mind out.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: 5 years old listening to that.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Neil Degrade
text: Yeah, man. Oh, dude. Yeah. That really just. That was it for me. That ruined me as far as being able to do anything normal with music. It all gotta be theatrical and cinematic from that point on.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -

text: Yeah.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: And that's an interesting aspect of your work which, you know, your bandpur. Robbins. There really is a storytelling aspect to the band. There's like a. Almost like you said, an operatic. There's some nostalgia. There's something melodramatic about the way that things are presented. And so I can really. I didn't. I wouldn't have thought right away Queen. But when you say it, I'm like, yeah, that makes a lot of sense that.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Neil Degrade
text: Well, there are definitely other influences in there. So Kate is really. The band is myself and my wife. And we've used a lot of other incredible musicians and people play with us over the years. But Kate and I met when I was in my early 20s and she is really the other half of the band. She kind of taught me, I would say, how to write lyrics. She already had a music career growing. We met, she was younger than me, but I was this really poor guy living in Providence, Rhode Island. And there was a musical that was auditioning in town. It was supposed to be going to Broadway. And some people showed me some examples of it and I thought it was incredible. But I had like zero interest in being in a musical. So I did not want to audition. But I was hitching a ride with my friends and they said they would drop me off where I wanted to go if I would just audition with them, which was strange. So the audition was really weird because generally it's like, you know, you see these in movies where there's this panel and people watching. And that was there. But it was also in an old church in New England. So everybody waiting to audition was still in the. Was in the audience. So you're auditioning in front of all these other people, which I didn't care about. Cause I didn't plan on doing a musical. There was one part left and they were auditioning the male lead. And they were like going nationwide trying to find this guy. Well, I got up to audition and I decided my job was going to be to make my friends laugh. And it somehow translated as, like, confidence and composure and stage presence. And I had very little experience in musicals. And so the next day, I get a call, and they're like, hey, listen, congratulations, you got the part. And I was like, oh, that's so nice. I don't want the part, though. Like, you know, I'm sure you've got. There were a lot of people there that were great. I'm sure you've got them there. And then. And so I turned it down. And then the writer of the musical called me back, and his name was in Rico Garzelli. And he was really interesting guy, but he started. He started explaining to me a very strange angle as why I should do this. He's like, I cast you because you go perfectly with the girl we cast for the lead. He said, you guys are going to want to. You're going to want to MARRY this girl 100%. And I think there's going to be incredible chemistry. And she was from Los Angeles. She auditioned out in the West Coast. And I was like, well, maybe I could show up to a couple of rehearsals. So I said yes, and I showed up. And the first meeting I had with Kate, where we had to sing is she just got in front of me, and her part in this duet went first, and she started to sing. And I'd never heard anything like this coming out of someone's mouth. Three feet. It's really uncomfortable to have someone staring you in the eyes with complete confidence and just singing at you. And it sounded so amazing. I was like, I am in way over my head. I am doomed here.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: And so anyway, we just like, I'm gonna marry her. That's how I'm gonna do it.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Audio Clips
text: He was so right.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Neil Degrade
text: He was so right. We got married, and we instantly started writing. She was a singer songwriter, and I was always in collaborations in bands, and she was like, a wordsmith. And so she instantly, like, turned my brain on to, like, that potential of music. Cause I was one of, like, those typical dudes that was interested in melody and music, But I was just like. Lyrics were just in the background of the song for me. And she, like, really gave me a love for that. So that's how really our band got started in our marriage and our kids. And so it's kind of everything.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: That's very fascinating.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: One of the things that bring us here is because your last album is kind of causing a stir in the symbolic world. World, you would say, because you wrote it, what, in 2018? Or you came out. When did you write it?

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Neil Degrade
text: Okay, so I guess there's other background required is that all of our albums, all of our, you know, the last 10 years have been concept albums where I'll write a story and then I will record. I'll write down the bullet points of that story and the most important moments, and then I'll write songs for those. So it's a really. I really think art flourishes. When I have structure for me, like, when I know and I have an assignment and a boundary to play within, I will write within those boundaries. So I write the story, and then we fill in the blanks with the song. So we are wrapping up a record called The Ravenlocks in 2017, 2018, which was one of the things about movies and music. A lot of times it's written long before you ever record it. So the Ravenlocks is wrapping up, and I needed a new story. So 2018 rolled around, and this was a weird way to come up with an idea for a record. So you're familiar with Airbnb, where you rent houses and travel. So we had rented a house on the Gulf coast of Florida to go on a vacation. But right when we were about to leave for the vacation, like, a red tide had taken over, and they weren't letting people on the beach where the house was, and they were evacuating. There were dead fish everywhere. It was horrible. And so I was like, of course I'm not going to be renting this house. So it sounded like a nightmare. So I messaged the guy. I was like, of course we're going to need to get out of this. He's like, oh, that's fine, but he's not going to give us our money back. And I was like, oh, gee, that's an interesting turn of events. So I looked into Airbnb's policy on, like, why you could cancel. And so as I'm scanning through, one of the things was a pandemic. And I was like, I hadn't really thought about a pandemic. Our previous story, because we write lighthearted stuff, had to do with cholera a little bit. So I knew a little bit about how these things function. But as I was starting to read about what made something qualify as a pandemic, the story, like, hit me. And I was like, oh, my gosh. Do you. Like, there's a. I've had this concern that our society, we're already, like, the social fabric is disintegrating, and people are already pushing for a part. And if there was just some Kind of like even mild pandemic. Like, what would be the implications of that? So I just started writing a story about that idea. So, yeah, 2020 rolled around and we had released almost. We released our records in chunks, almost like a pulp thing, where we were releasing in EPs and everything, but the last EP had come out. But it was weird because, like, there were things that were happening directly in the headlines that we were singing about. And it is what it is. I didn't. Wasn't trying to predict a pandemic. I was just paying attention to the world. And I generally write and deal with subjects that are troubling me because I think I make music. And I've never been able to stop myself from making music because it's how I stay sane. So I use art to kind of ground me and explore the story because it's easier for me to see how something fits together when it all comes together as a concept within art and music than it is to just abstractly just imagine what the world's actually working like. So that was where Deadhorse came from.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: So in Deadhorse you have this story, but there's also not just a pandemic. There's this whole idea of kind of the edge of the world, how all of this is related to. And there's not just the pandemic, but also the reaction to the pandemic and this idea of a world that is kind of shut down and. And how this, like, kind of this prison of. I don't know, how can I say this, like this prison that makes you safe but then also takes everything away from you at the same time.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Neil Degrade
text: Yeah, so, yeah. So what I did is I riffed on the idea of quarantine or a society that was riddled with series of quarantines for multiple reasons, from even reasons of personality, where ideologies were too different and people couldn't hear things they didn't like anymore, they were too fragile. And also the idea that people just saw everybody became a germaphobe and was afraid of what everybody else presented to them and the danger that presented, and also how companies would benefit from that and how all the new technology would benefit from that. So the story actually is this weird kind of like, I would say, like a Rip Van Winkle structure where the characters find the means to try to go into the future to escape what's happening. So it starts out in Dead Horse, Alaska, which is the namesake of the record. And Dead Horse, Alaska is in Prudhoe Bay in the north edge of the world. And that's where the Alaskan pipeline begins. And so the story starts when the Alaskan pipeline is turned on, and it's this power. And I, you know, I mythologized it. So they. I talk about that within the story as if they found, like, under some beast at the bottom of the ocean. And what were the implications of that thing and what were the desires of that beast? So as we moved into Deadhorse, you know, they go into the future, and they wake up 100 years later. I'm skipping really quickly just to get to the point of what you've asked, and that is that they wake up into a world. That's the world we live in now, but it's accelerated. So this pattern of spreading out, and everything's on a grid and everything's distanced, and people are, you know. Well, sadly, like they are now. We're communicating each other through a little window. Like, before we started, I picked, like, the best angle in here, and I put, like, my favorite gear in the shot, and so, like, gearheads would see it and, like, you know, all kind of breaking the wall. But this isn't what my life looks like. I mean, there's other angles of this trailer where I' pushed all the junk that I was working on. It was kind of a riff on some of these ideas and what that would do to personalities and people and also how technology would try to solve that.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: Yeah, yeah, yeah. So maybe we can look at some of the songs, because one of the things that I want to kind of bring about is this idea of pattern or pattern intuition. And so in 2019, I told people, get ready for 2020, because it's going to be crazy. And then some people later said, oh, Jonathan predicted the future. I'm like, I didn't predict the future. If you see a vase tipping on the side of a table, and then you tell people to watch out because it's falling, it's different. And I think that. I mean, obviously that's a simplified version, but I think there are some people that have an intuition about patterns. And so as you kind of look at the patterns and you talk about them, even without knowing it, you can end up doing something like predict the future without trying to do that explicitly. It's just this attention. Attention to the world, attention to patterns, and then kind of telling a story that ends up formulating this what's going on, even if it's implicit and it's not completely logical and understood yet.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Neil Degrade
text: Yeah, I mean, I guess before we dig into the story a little more that's really worth mentioning. So when we first got a record deal, we were making music independently. I was just making stuff on a computer at home, and it just started selling and I just quit my job. And I was like, oh, my gosh, this is going really well. And we did. The next thing you do is we try to find a record label. We had interest, and the problem with the record label was that they need to make money. And so what we were doing isn't like the most obvious way to make money. So there was this like, oh, they look at. They see talent or they see. They see something that's marketable, and then they try to package it within some kind of popular form. So there was this real push towards pop. And so my problem I always had when I was interacting with pop is I think I made my worst stuff because there's this tendency just to copy what everybody else is doing. You know, it's good when it fits the pattern, but you don't understand the pattern necessarily. So simultaneously, there was this other thing happening where it was kind of where I started seeing the world symbolically. And I didn't know it was a good way to see the world or the right way to see the world. I just knew there was power in it when it came to writing. So, like, what we talked about, you know, with this oil, and I personified the, you know, energy in the story. Or you could take. Cancel culture and you could give it some kind of monstrous description and describe, you know, come. Come up with some analogous ways that that monster might do the same thing. I realized there was so much. It was so much more impactful when I would take the patterns I was seeing and I would give them a will and an intelligence. And so that changed things. And also the other side of it that changed things is where we realized where we were going to be positioned as artists is that it was also. It takes place within a world that has a beginning, middle, and an end. And we, as we're writing, we found it was a way better sweet spot for us to imagine that this was the end. Like, it was that things were coming to a close and the pattern was about, you know, something new was ahead. So when once I started looking at this world in these symbolic patterns and, like, really starting to see monsters and, like, demons and things, whether they were there or not, I didn't know. It just. It suddenly it was like I had no end to the ideas anymore. It wasn't like I was trying to find an idea for a pop song. It was Like, I have more ideas right now than I know what to write about. It was changed in the way I was looking out of the window simultaneously. I was obsessed with Genesis. And the other part I felt was missing from the world was losing sight of what human nature was and why it was there. And I got obsessed with the story of the Garden of Eden because it was such incredible description of, like, these. These weird desires for perfection or to be divine or to be royal that we have, and that things shouldn't go wrong. And it just. It started to explain that in the story. So I always keep that story in mind when it comes to, like, how consciousness developed. And that interpretation of it is. I throw that over everything, whether people like it or not. Like, it's that.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: But it doesn't necessarily. Because you. You've internalized it. It doesn't necessarily appear that way. This is one of the things, too, that even in the discussion with my brother Mathieu, sometimes. Sometimes we would say something. We would think, like, oh, that's too obvious. Like, it's too obvious if we say something this way, or if we say it this way, it's too obvious. Then you realize, no, it's not. It's actually not. You see the connection. Like, if you're using analogies, you think that it's the same as something else, but people don't necessarily notice it. And so if you take the story of the Garden and you superimpose it over another event, most people won't see that it's the story of the Garden. Like, they'll just see that it has this amazing coherence to it, or this strange, intuitive coherence to it.

episode_id: SW - #151 - 2021-04-02 - Neil DeGraide - Can Artists Predict the Future -
speaker: Neil Degrade
text: Yeah. And people are so. I think they're just. We're sitting on top of so many things we didn't invent. We're sitting on top of so many things we used to have to do ourself. We're so detached from how we get our food and how even the car we drive operates or how it's built. We can't repair it. I can't fix the computer I'm using. We're sitting on top of all this stuff that just. We start to reason as if that's the actual starting point for reality. And all kinds of errors are being made everywhere. Where. Even. Especially in the political spheres. When you listen to the different ends of the political narrative, it's like it's totally detached from the substructure of what being is itself, what it means to be a person in this world. It seems so inorganic now. It's starting to. It causes a little bit of panic in me when I realize how people see themselves and what they think we are sometimes. And so really, the record at the end of the day is a discussion of your nature and what you're ignoring. Again, that wasn't my intention. But when I look back at it, it's trying to drive to the bottom of why you do what you do and why you want what you want, because we don't question those things nearly enough.
